choices.text: Normal pH can't rule out acid base disorder
Add 0.5 ml Heparin to the syringe before taking blood
If modified Allen’s test is negative, alternate site is chosen
Radial artery is the preferred site

questions.text: You are an intern posted in the ICU. While taking a blood sample for ABG, which of the following steps would you not do? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Add 0.5 ml Heparin to the syringe before taking blood

 

Explanation:

 

Add 0.5 ml Heparin to the syringe before taking blood: Traditionally, to prevent blood from clotting inside the syringe when obtaining an ABG, a small amount of heparin was added to the syringe. However, in contemporary practice, syringes used for ABG are pre-heparinized, which means they already contain a coating of dry heparin that will mix with the blood sample and prevent clotting. Adding additional heparin to such a syringe is unnecessary and can dilute the sample, potentially altering the results.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Normal pH can't rule out acid base disorder: This statement is accurate. A patient can have a mixed acid-base disorder where two primary disorders (e.g., metabolic acidosis and respiratory alkalosis) coexist and "cancel" each other out, leading to a seemingly "normal" pH. However, when the components of the arterial blood gas (ABG) like PaCO2 and HCO3- are evaluated, abnormalities can be detected.

 

Option C. If modified Allen’s test is negative, alternate site is chosen: The modified Allen's test is a simple way to evaluate the collateral blood flow to the hand via the ulnar artery. Before taking a sample or placing an arterial line in the radial artery, it's a recommended step to ensure that if the radial artery becomes occluded, the hand will still receive adequate blood flow. If the test is negative (indicative of inadequate collateral flow), it's safer to choose an alternate site for arterial puncture.

 

Option D. Radial artery is the preferred site: The radial artery is commonly chosen for ABG sampling and arterial line placement due to its accessibility, the presence of collateral blood flow (via the ulnar artery), and its relatively superficial location which makes puncture technically easier. Furthermore, complications like hematoma or injury are less problematic at this location when compared to other potential sites, such as the femoral artery.

 

Educational Objective :

 

Adding extra heparin to pre-heparinized ABG syringes is unnecessary and can alter the blood sample.

questions.text: A patient has the freedom to pick his or her caretaker and future course of action in treatment under the Mental Health Care Act of 2017. What is the name of this provision? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Advance directive

 

Under the Mental Health Care Act of 2017 in India, the provision allowing a patient to choose his or her caretaker and future course of action in treatment is termed the “Advance directive”. It is a legal document wherein the individual specifies the type of treatment they want or don't want, should they become mentally ill and be unable to make competent decisions in the future.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Treatment directive, Option B. Mental will, and Option C. Future directive are not the correct terms used in the context of the Mental Health Care Act of 2017.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Under the Mental Health Care Act 2017 in India, individuals can use an "Advance Directive" to state the way they wish to be treated for a mental illness and the way they wish not to be treated for a mental illness. This provision empowers individuals to have a say in their treatment even if they become incapacitated in the future. This is applicable only if a person loses the capacity to make mental healthcare or treatment decisions. Individuals can also appoint “Nominated Representative (NR)”, who will help in taking decisions regarding the treatment if he or she loses the capacity to make decision.

 

Reference: Forensic Psychiatry in India, Interface of Indian Laws and Mental Health, Page No 42.

questions.text: Macula densa is formed by which part of the nephron? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) DCT

 

 

Macula densa is formed by specialized tubular epithelial cells of the distal convoluted tubule. The juxtaglomerular complex consists of macula densa cells in the initial portion of the distal tubule and juxtaglomerular cells in the walls of the afferent and efferent arterioles.

 

The macula densa is a specialized group of epithelial cells in the distal tubules that comes in close contact with the afferent and efferent arterioles. The macula densa cells contain Golgi apparatus, which are intracellular secretory organelles directed toward the arterioles, suggesting that these cells may be secreting a substance toward the arterioles.

 

Tubuloglomerular feedback is the mechanism that regulates GFR through renal tubule and macula densa. When the glomerular filtrate passes through the terminal portion of thick ascending segment, macula densa acts like a sensor. It detects the concentration of sodium chloride in the tubular fluid and accordingly alters the glomerular blood flow and GFR. Macula densa detects the sodium chloride concentration via Na+K+2Cl– cotransporter (NKCC2).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. PCT (Proximal Convoluted Tubule): Incorrect. The proximal convoluted tubule is involved in the reabsorption of water, ions, and nutrients, but it does not form the macula densa.

 

Option C. Afferent arteriole: Incorrect. The afferent arteriole brings blood into the glomerulus and contains juxtaglomerular cells, but it does not form the macula densa.

 

Option D. Bowman's capsule: Incorrect. Bowman's capsule surrounds the glomerulus and is involved in the initial filtration of blood to form urine but does not form the macula densa.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The macula densa, formed by cells of the distal convoluted tubule (DCT), is crucial for sensing sodium chloride concentration in the tubular fluid and regulating glomerular filtration rate (GFR) through the tubuloglomerular feedback mechanism.

questions.text: The image given below shows neuromuscular monitoring of the patient after anesthesia. What is the most commonly used nerve for monitoring? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Ulnar nerve

 

  • To monitor adequacy of neuromuscular blockade ulnar nerve is preferred.
  • It is monitored using a Train of Four monitor/peripheral nerve stimulator.
  • Twitching of the adductor pollicis muscle is seen on electrical stimulation of the ulnar nerve.
  • The ulnar nerve is frequently used for monitoring neuromuscular blockade during and after anesthesia.
  • It is typically monitored using a device known as a Train of Four (TOF) monitor or peripheral nerve stimulator.
  • The ulnar nerve is accessible and provides a reliable location for monitoring. Twitching of the adductor pollicis muscle (a muscle in the thumb) is commonly observed when electrical stimulation is applied to the ulnar nerve.
  • This twitch response is used to assess the degree of neuromuscular blockade and the patient's recovery from anesthesia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Median nerve: While the median nerve can be used for neuromuscular monitoring, the ulnar nerve is more commonly preferred because of its accessibility and ease of stimulation. The adductor pollicis muscle twitch response is typically more reliable for assessing neuromuscular blockade compared to other muscles.

 

Option C. Radial nerve: The radial nerve can also be used for neuromuscular monitoring, but it is not as commonly chosen as the ulnar nerve. Similar to the median nerve, the ulnar nerve offers a more reliable and standard location for monitoring.

 

Option D. Metacarpal nerve: There is no specific nerve called the "metacarpal nerve" commonly used for neuromuscular monitoring.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The ulnar nerve is the most commonly used nerve for monitoring neuromuscular blockade, typically assessed using a Train of Four (TOF) monitor or peripheral nerve stimulator.

questions.text: Identify the 2nd generation supraglottic airway device from the options given below. (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) LMA Proseal

 

The LMA Proseal is a second-generation supraglottic airway device. Second-generation devices are designed to be safer than first-generation devices, offering a higher pressure pharyngeal seal and a reduced risk of aspiration. These devices often have two tubes: one for ventilation (airway tube) and another for draining gastric secretions (gastric tube). The LMA Proseal, specifically, features these characteristics, making it a second-generation device.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. LMA Fastrach: LMA Fastrach, also known as the intubating LMA, is not categorized as either a first or second-generation device. It is classified as a special LMA due to its unique design, which facilitates difficult intubations.

 

 

Option B. LMA Flexible: The LMA Flexible is a variant of the LMA Classic, which is a first-generation device. It has a flexible airway tube but lacks the features of second-generation devices, such as a high-pressure pharyngeal seal and an additional tube for gastric drainage.

 

 

Option D. Ambu LMA: The Ambu LMA does not have the dual-tube system that characterizes second-generation devices.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

LMA Proseal is a second-generation supraglottic airway device, identified by its two-tube system that enhances safety by reducing the risk of aspiration

questions.text: A 30-year-old man weighing 70 kg had a sodium level of 120 mEq, calculate sodium deficit? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 840 mEq

 

Explanation

 

The sodium deficit in the given scenario is 840 mEq.

 

Formula for calculating sodium deficit = 0.6 × body weight x (target plasma sodium concentration - starting plasma sodium concentration).

 

Substituting values as per the question,

 

Sodium deficit = 0.6 x 70 × (140 - 120) = 840 mEq.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Correcting sodium levels must be done cautiously, especially in cases of hyponatremia, to prevent complications like osmotic demyelination syndrome. Rapid changes in serum sodium can be dangerous, and adjustments should generally be made slowly, according to specific clinical guidelines.

questions.text: Glycopyrrolate is used as a preanesthetic agent for? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Reducing the secretions 

 

  • Mechanism of Action: Glycopyrrolate is an anticholinergic agent, which means it acts by blocking the action of acetylcholine on muscarinic receptors.
  • Effect: One of the effects of this action is the reduction in the production of secretions, such as saliva and bronchial mucus.
  • Clinical Use: Given before anesthesia, it can prevent excessive secretions that might interfere with the procedure or increase the risk of aspiration. Hence, this is the primary reason glycopyrrolate is used as a preanesthetic agent.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sedative effect: Glycopyrrolate does not have inherent sedative properties. While it may have some central side effects due to its anticholinergic action, its quaternary structure limits its ability to cross the blood-brain barrier. Thus, it doesn't produce sedation in the same manner as agents specifically designed for that purpose, like benzodiazepines.

 

Option C. Skeletal muscle relaxant: Glycopyrrolate does not have skeletal muscle relaxant properties.

 

Option D. Anxiolytic: Glycopyrrolate is not used as an anxiolytic.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Glycopyrrolate is primarily used as a preanesthetic agent to reduce secretions, thus preventing complications during anesthesia and surgery.

questions.text: What is the dose range of lithium in mEq/dL for acute attacks of mania and long-term maintenance?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 0.6 to 1.5 mEq/dL

 

Lithium has a narrow therapeutic window and its serum concentrations need careful monitoring.

 

0.6 to 1.5 mEq/dL represents the general therapeutic range for lithium. According to 12th edition of Synopsis of Psychiatry,  for acute manic episodes, the target serum lithium level is between 1.0 to 1.2 mEq/dL, while for long-term maintenance, it is 0.4 to 0.8 mEq/dL. The option closes to this range is option C.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 0.5 to 1 mEq/dL is close but not the typical therapeutic range. It is on the lower end and might not be effective for many patients, especially during acute mania.

 

Option B. 0.1 to 0.5 mEq/dL is subtherapeutic. Such low levels wouldn't be effective for the treatment of bipolar disorder and would not offer the necessary mood-stabilizing effects.

 

Option D. 2 to 3 mEq/dL is a toxic range. Lithium concentrations at this level can result in severe side effects and even life-threatening toxicity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The therapeutic serum concentration of lithium for bipolar disorder is 0.6–1.5 mEq/L, with 1.0–1.2 mEq/L targeted during acute mania and 0.4–0.8 mEq/L during maintenance. Serum levels must be closely monitored due to the risk of toxicity.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 655

questions.text: Match the following: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A-3, B-4, C-2, D-1

 

1. Delirium Tremens (A-3): Benzodiazepines like oxazepam are the first-line treatment for delirium tremens, along with thiamine supplementation. 

 

2. Opioid Overdose (B-4): Naloxone is the specific antidote for opioid overdose. It acts as an opioid antagonist and can rapidly reverse respiratory depression caused by opioids.

 

3. Alcohol Dependence (C-2): Acamprosate is used in alcohol dependence to maintain abstinence by modulating glutamatergic neurotransmission. It reduces craving for alcohol.

 

4. Smoking Cessation (D-1): Varenicline is the most effective medication for smoking cessation. It reduces cravings and withdrawal symptoms by acting as a partial agonist at nicotinic receptors

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A young male patient has been on 5 mg haloperidol for several days. However, he has been experiencing inner restlessness and a strong want to move for the past four days. The most likely diagnosis is: (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Akathisia

 

The patient is presenting with inner restlessness and a compelling desire to be in constant motion, which is consistent with akathisia. This is a common extrapyramidal side effect of antipsychotic medications like haloperidol.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tardive dyskinesia: Tardive dyskinesia is a late-onset extrapyramidal side effect that can present as involuntary, repetitive movements of the tongue (e.g., twisting, protrusion), jaw (e.g., chewing also called. 

 

Option C. Rabbit syndrome: Rabbit syndrome lips (e.g., smacking, puckering), trunk and extremities.

 

Option D. Acute dystonia: Acute dystonia is the earliest side effect of antipsychotic and is characterized by sudden onset of muscle spasms, typically in the head and neck, occurring within hours to days of drug initiation.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Akathisia is characterized by a sense of inner restlessness along with objective, observable movements such as fidgeting of legs, pacing around, inability to sit or stand in one place for a long time. They can present soon after starting the antipsychotic or after dosage adjustments. It is the most common extrapyramidal side effect of antipsychotics. Drug of choice is Propranolol (beta blockers).

 

Reference: The Maudsley Prescribing Guidelines in Psychiatry, 14th edition, Page No 114

choices.text: EMLA means equal mixture of LA
Methemoglobinemia is a complication of this cream
1 gm of 5% cream contains lignocaine 50mg

questions.text: Which of these is true regarding this? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Methemoglobinemia is a complication of this cream 

 

The cream shown in the image is EMLA cream, which is a topical anesthetic. EMLA cream contains a combination of two local anesthetics, lidocaine and prilocaine, in a 1:1 ratio. One of the known complications of EMLA cream is methemoglobinemia. This condition can occur, especially when the cream is used in large quantities or in patients with certain predispositions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. EMLA means equal mixture of LA: EMLA means Eutectic mixture of LA and not equal mixture of LA.

 

Option B. It contains lignocaine and ropivacaine: This option is incorrect because EMLA cream does not contain ropivacaine. The active ingredients in EMLA cream are lidocaine (lignocaine) and prilocaine.

 

Option D. 1 gm of 5% cream contains lignocaine 50mg: This option is also incorrect. 1 gram of EMLA 5% cream contains 25mg of lidocaine and 25mg of prilocaine, not 50mg of lidocaine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

EMLA cream can cause methemoglobinemia as a complication, especially when used inappropriately or in large quantities.

questions.text:
Which of the following equipment is required for putting intravenous cannula in a newborn?(INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. 22G cannula

  2. 24G IV cannula

  3. 5-mL syringe

  4. Adhesive tape

  5. Normal saline
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 2,3,4,5

 

Explanation:

 

2. 24G IV cannula: This refers to a 24-gauge (24G) cannula, which is typically used for neonates and infants due to its smaller diameter, making it suitable for their small and fragile veins.

3. 5-mL syringe: While placing an IV cannula, it's essential to have a syringe attached. The syringe helps to test the patency of the cannula once it's in the vein (flashback of blood can be seen), and it also assists in gently flushing the cannula with normal saline to ensure it's correctly positioned.

4. Adhesive tape: Once the cannula is in position, adhesive tape or a securement device is necessary to stabilize and fix the cannula in place, preventing it from dislodging.

5. Normal saline: Normal saline is used for flushing the cannula once it's in place to ensure patency. It's also utilized to keep the cannula patent if it's not immediately hooked up to an IV line.

 

Other Option:

 

1. 22G IV cannula: A 22-gauge (22G) cannula is larger and may be used for older infants or children but is often too large for a newborn's tiny veins. Hence, it is not typically used for neonates.

 

Educational Objective :

 

For placing an IV cannula in a newborn, the equipment required includes a 24G needle, a 5-mL syringe, adhesive tape, and normal saline.

questions.text: What condition can lead to the characteristic waveform on capnography displayed by a patient under general anesthesia as observed on the ET CO2 monitor? (INICET May 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bronchospasm

 

Shark Fin appearance seen in bronchospasm due to anaphylaxis.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Malignant hyperthermia:

 

 

Option C. Rebreathing:

 

 

Option D. Accidental extubation

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Shark Fin appearance seen in bronchospasm is due to anaphylaxis.

questions.text: IV anesthetic agent that causes adrenocortical suppression is: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Etomidate

 

Etomidate causes adrenocortical suppression by inhibiting the 11-beta hydroxylase enzyme in the adrenal cortex. This enzyme is responsible for steroid production in the body. When etomidate inhibits this enzyme, it reduces steroid production, which can lead to adrenocortical suppression. Due to this effect, etomidate should be avoided in critically ill or septic patients where maintaining adequate steroid levels is important for hemodynamic stability.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Propofol: Does not cause adrenocortical suppression. It acts mainly through GABA receptors and affects the central nervous system.

 

Option C. Thiopentone: A barbiturate that acts on GABA receptors but does not affect adrenal function or steroid synthesis.

 

Option D. Ketamine: An NMDA receptor antagonist that actually stimulates the sympathetic system and may increase steroid levels rather than suppress them.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Etomidate causes adrenocortical suppression by inhibiting 11-beta hydroxylase enzyme in the adrenal cortex, making it unsuitable for use in critically ill or septic patients who require normal steroid function.

questions.text: Which of the following is not classified as OCD as per ICD 11? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) PTSD

 

The International Classification of Diseases (ICD-11), like the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM-5), classifies a number of disorders under the umbrella of obsessive-compulsive and related disorders. However, PTSD (Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder) is not classified as an obsessive-compulsive-related disorder in ICD-11. Instead, it's classified under trauma- and stressor-related disorders.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Trichotillomania: This is classified as an obsessive-compulsive-related disorder in ICD-11.

 

Option B. Body dysmorphic disorder: This too is categorized as an obsessive-compulsive-related disorder in ICD-11.

 

Option C. Hypochondriac disorder: Now termed "Illness Anxiety Disorder" in DSM-5, this is categorized as an obsessive-compulsive-related disorder in ICD-11.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Obsessive-compulsive or related disorders in ICD-11 are classified as:

 

  • Obsessive-compulsive disorder
  • Body dysmorphic disorder
  • Olfactory reference disorder
  • Hypochondriasis
  • Hoarding disorder
  • Trichotillomania
  • Excoriation disorder

 

Reference: International Classification of Diseases, 11th edition, Page No 43-47

questions.text: Identify the marked area in the given spirometry graph?  (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Functional residual capacity

 

Explanation:

 

The marked area in the spirometry graph indicates the Functional Residual Capacity (FRC). FRC is the volume of air remaining in the lungs after a normal, passive exhalation. This is not fully expelled during a standard tidal cycle and represents the air that remains in the lungs to keep them inflated.

 

  • FRC Components:
    • FRC includes the Expiratory Reserve Volume (ERV) plus the Residual Volume (RV).
    • ERV is the additional air that can be forcibly exhaled after the end of a normal, calm exhalation.
    • RV is the volume of air still remaining in the lungs after the most forceful exhalation, which cannot be voluntarily expelled.

 

 

Significance in Spirometry:

 

In spirometry:

 

  • FRC is critical for maintaining the alveolar inflation and preventing the airways from collapsing.
  • It is not directly measurable by simple spirometry because it includes the residual volume. Techniques such as body plethysmography or using tracer gas dilution methods are usually employed to measure FRC.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tidal Volume (TV or VT): This is the volume of air inhaled or exhaled during a normal breathing cycle, not indicated in this context.

 

Option C. Expiratory Reserve Volume (ERV): Part of FRC, this is the maximum volume of air that can be voluntarily expelled after the end of a normal, passive exhalation.

 

Option D. Expiratory Capacity: It is the total amount of air that can be expired from the lungs after a maximal inhalation, typically including the tidal volume plus the expiratory reserve volume, not specifically marked here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Functional Residual Capacity (FRC) is the volume of air remaining in the lungs after a normal expiration and is essential for preventing lung collapse and maintaining pulmonary function, especially during physical activities or respiratory challenges. Understanding FRC's role helps in assessing lung health and diagnosing potential respiratory disorders.

choices.text: Inside the membrane
At the C-terminal
At the N-terminal
Both inside the membrane and at C- terminal

questions.text: The signaling sequence in a type 2 membrane protein with N-terminal facing cytoplasm is located in?(INICET May 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Inside the membrane

 

The signaling sequence in a type 2 membrane protein is located inside the membrane.

 

These sequences usually have methionine as the terminal amino acid.

 

Transmembrane proteins are integral proteins that span across the plasma/ endoplasmic reticulum (ER) membrane. They are classified into types 1 to 4. –

 

Type 1 membrane proteins have a cleavable N-terminal signal sequence outside the cell, a transmembrane sequence that is usually situated close to the C-terminus and the C-terminus facing inside the cell, e.g., low-density lipoprotein receptor.

 

Type 2 membrane proteins have the N-terminal towards the cytosol and the C-terminal towards the exterior, e.g., transferrin receptor.

 

Type 3 membrane proteins are identical to type 1 but have a shorter N terminal, e.g., cytochrome P450 enzyme complexes.

 

Type 4 membrane proteins consist of 7 alpha helices traversing the membrane, e.g., glucose transporters and G-protein-coupled receptors.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. At the C-terminal: This is incorrect because the signaling sequence in type 2 membrane proteins is not located at the C-terminal.

 

Option C. At the N-terminal: This is incorrect as well. In type 2 membrane proteins, the N-terminal is facing the cytoplasm, but the signaling sequence itself is located inside the membrane.

 

Option D. Both inside the membrane and at C-terminal: This is incorrect because the signaling sequence is located specifically inside the membrane, not at the C-terminal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The signaling sequence in type 2 membrane proteins is located inside the membrane, crucial for the proper orientation and insertion of the protein.

questions.text: A patient believes he is the most important person in the world, his neighbors and family members are attempting to hurt him out of jealousy. His wife claims contrary, claiming that he has only recently begun acting in this manner, and that he previously worked calmly as a school teacher. He's probably suffering from? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Delusion of grandiosity and persecution

 

The patient's belief that he is the most important person in the world indicates a delusion of grandiosity. His belief that his neighbors and family members are attempting to hurt him due to jealousy represents a delusion of persecution. Both types of delusions are present in this scenario.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Delusion of grandiosity: Delusion of grandiosity is evident, but this choice doesn't encompass the persecutory beliefs he holds.

 

Option B. Delusion of persecution: While the patient does display delusions of persecution, this choice neglects the grandiose delusion.

 

Option D. Delusion of grandiosity, persecution and reference: The patient clearly exhibits delusions of grandiosity and persecution, but there's no evidence in the provided information suggesting a delusion of reference.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Delusional disorders are characterized by the presence of one or more delusions that persist for at least one month.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page 245-246.

questions.text: Which of the following physiological adaptations is generally not observed at high altitudes? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Respiratory acidosis

 

The physiological adaptation that does not happen at high altitudes is respiratory acidosis. Respiratory alkalosis is the physiological adaptation seen at high altitudes due to hyperventilation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pulmonary vasoconstriction: Correct, as it is a physiological response to low oxygen levels to improve gas exchange.

 

Option B. Polycythemia: Correct, as it increases the blood's oxygen-carrying capacity.

 

Option D. Hypoxia: Correct, as it is the primary condition caused by low oxygen levels at high altitudes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The principal means by which acclimatization to high altitude comes about are

 

  1. A great increase in pulmonary ventilation - increase in pulmonary ventilation on rising to a high altitude blows off large quantities of carbon dioxide, reducing the Pco2 and increasing the ph of the body fluids.
  2. Increased numbers of red blood cells,
  3. Increased diffusing capacity of the lungs,
  4. Increased vascularity of the peripheral tissues
  5. Increased ability of the tissue cells to use oxygen despite low Po2.
  6. Cellular Acclimatization - cell mitochondria and cellular oxidative enzyme systems are slightly more plentiful than in sea-level inhabitants

questions.text: Match the Following hormones to receptors: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1-A, 2-B, 3-C, 4-D

 

  1. Insulin - Tyrosine Kinase Pathway: Insulin uses a tyrosine kinase receptor. This is a cell surface receptor that, when activated, phosphorylates tyrosine residues on target proteins, triggering intracellular signaling cascades.
  2. Growth Hormone - JAK-STAT Pathway: Growth hormone, along with prolactin and leptin, uses the JAK-STAT (Janus Kinase-Signal Transducer and Activator of Transcription) pathway. This is a cytokine receptor-mediated signaling mechanism.
  3. Acetylcholine - Ligand-gated Channel: At the neuromuscular junction, acetylcholine operates through ligand-gated sodium channels. When acetylcholine binds, these channels open, allowing sodium ions to flow and triggering muscle contraction.
  4. Levothyroxine (Thyroid Hormone) - Nuclear Receptor: Thyroid hormones act through nuclear receptors, which means they enter the cell and directly interact with DNA in the nucleus to regulate gene expression.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Classification of Receptors

questions.text:
Which of the following are properties of ventricular muscle fibers: (INICET MAY 2024)

 

  1. All or none law
  2. Length-tension relation
  3. Tetanus
  4. Long refractory period
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 2, and 4

 

Explanation

 

Ventricular muscle fibers exhibit several unique properties that are crucial for their function:

 

1. All or None Law: This principle states that a single muscle fiber will either contract fully or not at all in response to a stimulus. Ventricular muscle fibers act as a syncytium due to the presence of gap junctions made up of connexin proteins, which allows them to follow the all-or-none law. Thus, this property is true for ventricular muscle fibers.

 

2. Length-Tension Relation: The length-tension relationship in ventricular muscle fibers is a reflection of the Frank-Starling law, which states that the force of contraction of the heart muscle is proportional to its initial length (or end-diastolic volume, EDV). This relationship is crucial for adjusting cardiac output based on the volume of blood returning to the heart. Within physiological limits, an increase in the initial length of the muscle fiber increases the force of contraction.

 

4. Long Refractory Period: Ventricular muscle fibers have a long refractory period due to the extended plateau phase in their action potential. This long refractory period is crucial in preventing tetanus and ensuring that the heart muscle relaxes fully before the next contraction, maintaining efficient pumping action.

 

Other Option:

 

3. Tetanus: Tetanus is a sustained muscle contraction that occurs when the muscle is stimulated at a high frequency. However, due to the long refractory period in ventricular muscle fibers, tetanus is not possible. The plateau phase (phase 2) of the cardiac action potential is prolonged, which ensures that the heart muscle cannot be re-stimulated before the previous contraction is complete. This prevents sustained contractions (tetanus), which would be detrimental to cardiac function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ventricular muscle fibers follow the all-or-none law, have a length-tension relationship (Frank-Starling law), and possess a long refractory period that prevents tetanus.

questions.text: A patient was prescribed escitalopram. Which of the following adverse effect is the least likely?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Sialorrhea

 

Escitalopram is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI). 

 

Sialorrhea is not typically associated with SSRIs. They are more likely to cause dry mouth. Sialorrhea is a common side effect of clozapine

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nausea: Nausea is a common side effect of SSRIs.

 

Option B. Vivid dreams: Vivid dreams can occasionally be reported but are not the most common side effect.

 

Option C. Anorgasmia: Anorgasmia or other sexual side effects are also commonly associated with SSRIs.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Side effects of SSRIs include:

 

  • Most common: Nausea
  • Most common long-term side effects: Sexual dysfunction including delayed orgasm, poor erection and low libido.
  • CNS side effects- Paradoxical anxiety, sedation, vivid dreams, sweating, seizures, EPSE etc.
  • QTc prolongation
  • Weight gain

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Comprehensive Textbook of Psychiatry, 10th edition, Page No 3156-3158

questions.text: Given below is the demonstration of tetanisation in the gastrocnemius muscle of a frog. Identify the tetanising frequency? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 20-25 Hz

 

Tetanizing frequency demonstrated by the muscle is 25Hz.

 

Tetanizing frequency: Rate of stimulation at which summation of contractions will occur

 

Tetanizing frequency can be calculated as à 1/contraction period.

 

As per the graph -

  • ﻿﻿Paper speed - 1000mm/sec.
  • ﻿﻿y-axis represents force of muscle contraction millivolts
  • x-axis represents duration of contraction in milliseconds with a scale of 10mm
  • ﻿﻿The scale on the x-axis is 10mm.
  • ﻿﻿Area under the graph is the muscle contraction.

 

Contraction period the duration from latent period to maximum force of contraction

So, in the given graph,

Contraction period is approximately 4 scales i.e., 40 mm.

As the speed of the paper is 1000mm/sec, contraction period = 40mm = (40/1000) = 40 msec = 0.04sec

Tetanizing frequency = 1/contraction period = 1/0.04 = 100/4 = 25Hz.

 

Educational Objective

 

Tetanisation

 

As the frequency increases, there comes a point where each new contraction occurs before the preceding one is over. As a result, the second contraction is added partially to the first, so that the total strength of contraction rises progressively with increasing frequency. When the frequency reaches a critical level, the successive contractions eventually become so rapid that they fuse together, and the whole muscle contraction appears to be completely smooth and continuous. This is called tetanization.

questions.text: In a patient with suspected endocrine dysfunction, which hormone primarily acts through the signaling pathway shown in the diagram below, potentially contributing to the patient's condition? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Leptin

 

The provided image depicts the JAK-STAT signaling pathway, known for its association with tyrosine kinase receptors. Within this pathway, leptin operates as one of the hormones involved. Leptin binds to its receptor, activating the JAK-STAT signaling cascade. This pathway is crucial for regulating energy balance and body weight, and its dysfunction can lead to endocrine and metabolic disorders. Leptin's role in this pathway highlights its importance in physiological processes and potential involvement in the patient's endocrine dysfunction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Calcitonin: Calcitonin primarily uses a different signaling mechanism involving G-protein-coupled receptors, not the JAK-STAT pathway.

 

Option C. Vasopressin: Vasopressin operates through G-protein-coupled receptors, particularly influencing water reabsorption in the kidneys, and does not utilize the JAK-STAT signaling pathway.

 

Option D. Aldosterone: Aldosterone acts mainly through mineralocorticoid receptors, influencing sodium and potassium balance in the kidneys, and is not involved in the JAK-STAT signaling pathway.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following is not a type of subcortical dementia?(INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pick's disease

 

To approach this question, we need to differentiate between cortical and subcortical dementias.

 

This is a type of frontotemporal dementia and is cortical. It primarily affects the frontal and temporal lobes. Memory may be preserved in the early stages, but personality and language changes are prominent. Therefore, it doesn't fall under the subcortical category, making it the correct answer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Parkinson's disease: Parkinson's primarily affects the basal ganglia in the brain, which is a subcortical structure. The primary symptoms are motoric (tremor, rigidity, bradykinesia), but dementia can develop in the later stages of the disease.

 

Option C. Huntington's disease: This is a genetic disorder that affects the basal ganglia, especially the caudate nucleus, which is also a subcortical structure. Cognitive decline and psychiatric symptoms are common.

 

Option D. Wilson's disease: This is a genetic disorder that leads to copper accumulation in the body, including the brain. The basal ganglia is one of the primary areas affected, making the dementia subcortical in nature.

 

Given the options, Pick's disease is the only cortical dementia, making it the correct answer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Reference: A Short Textbook of Psychiatry, 7th edition, Page No 24.

choices.text: Central line insertion
Arterial line insertion

questions.text: The given set of instruments are used in? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Airway management

 

Explanation:

 

The instruments shown in the image are part of an airway cart. The equipment typically found in an airway cart is designed for managing the airway during anesthesia or in emergency situations. The contents of the airway cart usually include:

 

  • Laryngoscope: A device used to obtain a view of the vocal folds and the glottis, which is essential for endotracheal intubation.
  • Tracheal tubes of various sizes: These tubes are used to secure the airway by passing through the trachea.
  • Masks: Various types of masks to deliver oxygen or anesthetic gases.
  • Laryngeal mask airways (LMA): A device placed over the laryngeal inlet to provide ventilation.
  • Flexible fiberoptic intubation equipment: Used for intubation in difficult airway situations.
  • Retrograde intubation equipment: Tools used for intubation when conventional methods fail.
  • Front of neck access equipment: Devices for surgical airway access.
  • Equipment required for emergency invasive airway access: Tools needed for emergency tracheostomy or cricothyrotomy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Central line insertion: This procedure requires different instruments such as central venous catheters, guidewires, dilators, and sterile drapes.

 

Option B. Arterial line insertion: This involves the use of arterial catheters, guidewires, and transducers, not typically found in an airway cart.

 

Option D. Cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR): CPR primarily requires defibrillators, chest compression devices, and basic airway management tools like bag-valve masks (BVM), but not the comprehensive set shown for airway management.

 

Educational Objective :

 

The instruments in an airway cart are specifically designed for various procedures involved in airway management, including intubation and emergency airway access.

questions.text: Identify the maneuver being performed in the given image? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Head tilt, chin lift

 

The maneuver performed in the given image is that of a head-tilt chin-lift. It is an important technique in emergency airway management to open up the airway.

 

  • Tilt the patient’s head back by pushing down on the forehead.
  • Place the tips of your index and middle fingers under the chin and pull up on the mandible (not on the soft tissues). This lifts the tongue away from the posterior pharynx and improves airway patency.

 

There is no absolute contraindication to it but Suspected cervical injury is a relative contraindication.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Jaw thrust: Lift the mandible upward with your fingers, at least until the lower incisors are higher than the upper incisors. This maneuver lifts the tongue along with the mandible, thus relieving upper airway obstruction.

 

 

Option D. Manual inline stabilization: is a neck immobilisation technique in a natural position achieved by using the fingers and palms of both hands to stabilize the patient's occiput and mastoid processes to gently counteract the forces of airway intervention

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The head-tilt chin-lift maneuver is a key technique for opening the airway in emergency situations, especially when cervical spine injury is not suspected.

questions.text: A person often feels that his hands are contaminated and he is forced to wash his hands. Recently, he feels this repetitive, distressing thought of repetitive hand washing has begun affecting his performance. Which of the following is the best treatment option for this patient? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Exposure and response prevention

 

The patient's symptoms are consistent with Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (OCD). One of the most effective treatments for OCD is Exposure and Response Prevention (ERP), which is a type of Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) specific for OCD.

 

Exposure and response prevention is the mainstay treatment for OCD.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. DBT (Dialectical Behavior Therapy): DBT is primarily used for borderline personality disorder and other self-harming behaviors.

 

Option C. Systematic desensitization: Systematic desensitization is a behavioral technique mainly used to treat phobias by gradually exposing the patient to the phobic stimulus.

 

Option D. CBT (Cognitive Behavioral Therapy): CBT is a broader therapeutic technique and is used in a variety of psychiatric disorders.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

For OCD, Exposure and Response Prevention (ERP), a specialized form of CBT, is the evidence-based first-line treatment. It involves exposing patients to their obsessional triggers while refraining from performing their compulsive rituals, gradually reducing the distress elicited by obsessions.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 425.

questions.text: What is the oxygen carrying capacity of 18-year-old boy with Hb of 14g/dl? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 18 mL/dL

 

The oxygen carrying capacity of blood is determined by the haemoglobin (Hb) concentration.

 

The average oxygen carrying capacity of haemoglobin is approximately 1.34 mL of oxygen per gram of haemoglobin.

 

Oxygen carrying capacity formula:

 

  • Oxygen Carrying Capacity = Hb (g/dL) × 1.34 mL/g

 

Substituting the given value:

 

  • Oxygen Carrying Capacity = 14 g/dL × 1.34 mL/g
  • Oxygen Carrying Capacity = 18.76 mL/dL
  • Therefore, the estimated oxygen carrying capacity for an 18-year-old boy with a haemoglobin concentration of 14 g/dL is approximately 18.76 mL/dL.

 

Educational Objective


The oxygen carrying capacity of blood is approximately 1.34 mL of oxygen per gram of hemoglobin, a crucial metric in assessing the oxygenation potential of blood in clinical settings.

questions.text: A patient undergoing surgery is maintained on anesthesia with halothane. During the procedure, the patient suddenly developed hyperthermia and muscle rigidity. Which of the following drugs is most likely implicated in this condition? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Suxamethonium

 

The scenario described involves a patient undergoing surgery who suddenly develops hyperthermia and muscle rigidity. This is indicative of a condition called Malignant Hyperthermia (MH), which is a rare but potentially life-threatening reaction to certain medications used during anesthesia.

 

In this case, the most likely drug implicated in causing MH is:

 

Suxamethonium (also known as succinylcholine)

 

  • Suxamethonium is a depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agent commonly used for muscle relaxation during surgery.
  • However, it is known to be associated with triggering malignant hyperthermia in susceptible individuals.
  • MH is a severe reaction that can cause a rapid increase in body temperature, muscle rigidity, and other complications.

 

Other Options :

 

Option A. Doxacurium: Doxacurium is a non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agent used to induce muscle relaxation during surgery. It is not typically associated with causing malignant hyperthermia.

 

Option C. Atracurium: Atracurium is another non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agent used in anesthesia. It is not typically associated with causing malignant hyperthermia.

 

Option D. Rocuronium: Rocuronium is also a non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agent. Like atracurium and doxacurium, it is not typically associated with causing malignant hyperthermia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The drug most likely implicated in causing malignant hyperthermia in the given scenario is suxamethonium (succinylcholine) because it is known to trigger this condition in susceptible individuals.

 

Treatment - Dantrolene sodium and supportive management

choices.text: Watch for spontaneous breaths and re-intubate if needed

questions.text: A patient who was on a ventilator for one week suddenly gets agitated and self-extubates himself. What is the next step of management? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Watch for spontaneous breaths and re-intubate if needed

 

  • This is the most logical and safest immediate action. By observing the patient's spontaneous breathing, clinicians can gauge whether the patient is in distress or if they're maintaining their airway and oxygenating adequately. Self-extubation doesn't automatically necessitate re-intubation. If the patient is breathing well and does not desaturate, self-extubated patients may not require re-intubation. This can be confirmed by doing an arterial blood gas of the patient and checking his PaO2/FiO2 ratio and also watching for spontaneous breathing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Re-intubate: Simply re-intubating without assessment can be a precipitous action. It might be unnecessary if the patient can maintain their airway and oxygenation without assistance. Additionally, re-intubation has its own set of risks, including injury to the airway, so it's not a decision to be taken lightly.

 

Option B. Oxygenate and re-intubate: While it's always important to ensure a patient is well-oxygenated, especially if there's potential for re-intubation, the decision to re-intubate should be based on the patient's clinical status and not solely on the fact that they've self-extubated.

 

Option C. Start CPR: Cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) is initiated in situations of cardiac arrest. There's no indication in the scenario that the patient's heart has stopped. Starting CPR without evidence of cardiac arrest can cause harm, including broken ribs and internal injury.

 

Educational Objective :

 

  • Self-extubation requires careful assessment to determine if re-intubation is necessary. Observing the patient's spontaneous breathing and oxygenation status is crucial before making the decision to re-intubate.

questions.text: Which of the following local  anaesthetic causes hypertension?(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cocaine

 

Cocaine: An ester local anesthetic that is also a powerful central nervous system stimulant. One of the well-known cardiovascular effects of cocaine is hypertension, due to its potent vasoconstrictive properties.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lignocaine: is an amide local anesthetic that is used to produce numbness during procedures and for treating various types of pain. It can cause side effects such as dizziness and low blood pressure but is not known for causing hypertension.

 

Option C. Bupivacaine: An amide local anesthetic known for its potent and long-lasting numbing effect. It can cause cardiovascular complications, but like lignocaine, it is more associated with cardiac toxicity rather than hypertension.

 

Option D. Prilocaine: Another amide local anesthetic, similar to lignocaine, and not commonly associated with causing hypertension.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Cocaine is the local anesthetic known to cause hypertension due to its vasoconstrictive effects.

questions.text: Which is the first-order neuron in the optic pathway? (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Rods and cones

 

  • The rods and cones act as the first-order neurons They give the signals to the bipolar cells act as second order neurons in the optic pathway. They serve as an intermediate link between the photoreceptor cells and the ganglion cells (option B), which are the third-order neurons.
  • The electrical signals from the bipolar cells are further transmitted to the ganglion cells. The axons of ganglion cells form the optic nerve, which carries visual information from the retina to the visual processing centers in the brain.
  • The optic nerve fibers project to different regions of the brain, including the lateral geniculate body (option C), which is part of the thalamus and is involved in visual processing. Therefore, the correct correct answer is A.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Ganglion cells: Incorrect. Ganglion cells are the third-order neurons in the optic pathway.

 

Option C. Cells in lateral geniculate body: Incorrect. These cells are involved in the later stages of visual processing and are not first-order neurons.

 

Option D. Bipolar cells: Incorrect. Bipolar cells are the second-order neurons in the optic pathway.

 

Educational Objective

 

In the optic pathway, the first-order neurons are the photoreceptor cells, specifically rods and cones, which convert light into electrical signals. These signals are then relayed through bipolar cells to ganglion cells, whose axons form the optic nerve, ultimately transmitting visual information to the brain.

questions.text: Which of the following is the diluting segment of the kidney? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ascending thick loop of Henle

 

The thick ascending limb has a sodium hydrogen counter-transport mechanism in its luminal

cell membrane that mediates sodium reabsorption and hydrogen secretion in this segment.

 

The thick segment of the ascending loop of Henle is virtually impermeable to water.
 

Therefore, most of the water delivered to this segment remains in the tubule, despite reabsorption of large amounts of solute. The tubular fluid in the ascending limb becomes very dilute as it flows toward the distal tubule. Hence it is called the diluting segment of the kidney.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. PCT (Proximal Convoluted Tubule): Incorrect. The PCT is primarily involved in reabsorbing water, sodium, and other solutes, but it is not considered the diluting segment.

 

Option B. Collecting duct: Incorrect. The collecting duct is involved in the reabsorption of water and solutes and is influenced by hormones like ADH, but it is not the primary diluting segment.

 

Option D. Descending loop of Henle: Incorrect. The descending loop of Henle is permeable to water but not to solutes, making it responsible for concentrating the tubular fluid, not diluting it.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The thick ascending loop of Henle is the diluting segment of the kidney due to its impermeability to water and active reabsorption of solutes

choices.text: It most commonly affects ages 35-45 years
Type 1 is common in both sexes
Attempt to commit suicide is seen around 15% of people

questions.text: Which of the following is false about bipolar disorder? (INICET May 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) It most commonly affects ages 35-45 years

 

Bipolar disorder, historically called manic-depressive illness, often begins in late adolescence or early adulthood. While it can start in childhood or later in life, this is less common.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Type 1 is common in both sexes: True. Bipolar I disorder has no gender bias and affects men and women equally.

 

Option C. Prevalence in the general population is 1-2%: True. Bipolar disorder affects about 1-2% of the global population.

 

Option D. Attempt to commit suicide is seen in around 15% of people: True. People with bipolar disorder have a high suicide risk, and approximately 15% may end up taking their own life.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Bipolar disorder typically presents in late adolescence or early adulthood. It is characterized by episodes of mania and depression, affects both sexes equally, has a prevalence of 1-2% in the general population, and carries a significant risk of suicide.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 376.

questions.text: X, Y, Z are three permeable ions. X = -50 and Y = -30. At RMP, if there is no net electrogenic transfer, what is the value of Z? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) + 80

 

No net electrogenic transfer at RMP implies that X + Y + Z = 0

 

So, - 50 + (-30) + Z =0

 

Z = 50 + 30 = 80

 

Educational Objective:

 

No net electrogenic transfer at resting membrane potential (RMP) implies that the sum of the equilibrium potentials of the ions is zero

questions.text: Identify the ions A and B based on conductance graph of a neuron shown below: (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Na, K

 

Channel A: Na+, Channel B: K+

 

During the early portion of the action potential, the ratio of sodium to potassium conductance increases more than 1000-fold. Therefore, far more sodium ions flow to the interior of the fiber than do potassium ions to the exterior. This causes the membrane potential to become positive at the action potential onset.

 

Then the sodium channels begin to close and the potassium channels to open, so that the ratio of conductance shifts far in favor of high potassium conductance but low sodium conductance. This allows very rapid loss of potassium ions to the exterior but virtually zero flow of sodium ions to the interior.

Consequently, the action potential quickly returns to its baseline level.

 

Educational Objective:

 

During an action potential, sodium conductance increases first (Channel A), followed by an increase in potassium conductance (Channel B), causing depolarization and subsequent repolarization of the neuron.

questions.text: Duration of action of Proparacaine? (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 20 mins

 

Proparacaine:

 

  • Duration of Action: The duration of action of proparacaine is approximately 15-20 minutes.
  • Uses: Proparacaine hydrochloride is used as a topical anesthetic agent, especially for ophthalmic surgeries such as:
    • Tonometry
    • Gonioscopy
    • Removal of corneal foreign bodies
    • Short corneal and conjunctival procedures

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The duration of action of proparacaine is approximately 15-20 minutes, making it suitable for short ophthalmic procedures.

questions.text: In this case, a young boy is exhibiting symptoms of reduced mood, decreased energy, and diminished engagement with his environment. He has refrained from eating for the past week and his thoughts include phrases like "I have lost my mind. I am deceased. How can I consume food?". What is the specific delusion in this scenario? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Nihilistic delusion

 

Nihilistic delusion (delusion of negation, Cotard syndrome Option A): Patients may deny the existence of their body, their mind, or the world in general. For example, a patient with severe depression claimed that all his internal organs have rotted.

 

Here, the best answer is Nihilistic delusion rather than Cotard syndrome because the question has specifically asked the type of delusion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hypochondriacal delusion: Hypochondriacal delusion is an illness anxiety disorder. It is characterized by a preoccupation with having or acquiring a serious physical illness. The preoccupation persists despite normal investigations and medical reassurances.

 

Option D. Bizarre delusion: Scientifically impossible and culturally implausible (un-understandable). For example, a patient claimed that aliens stole his heart and lungs, and now he is living without those organs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A nihilistic delusion is a false belief that the self or the world no longer exists. It is a hallmark feature of severe depressive psychosis and can occur within Cotard’s syndrome, but it is distinct as a type of delusion.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a contraindication to the use of morphine? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Acute myocardial infarction

 

Explanation:

 

Acute myocardial infarction: Morphine is often used in the setting of acute myocardial infarction (AMI) to relieve pain and anxiety. It also has the beneficial effect of reducing preload and afterload on the heart, which can decrease myocardial oxygen demand. This makes it beneficial in the management of AMI. It's not a contraindication.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bronchial asthma: Morphine can induce histamine release, which may lead to bronchospasm. In patients with bronchial asthma, this bronchospasm can exacerbate respiratory difficulties, making morphine potentially dangerous for these patients.

 

Option B. Renal failure: Morphine is metabolized in the liver and its metabolites, especially morphine-6-glucuronide, are excreted by the kidneys. In the case of renal failure, these active metabolites can accumulate, leading to prolonged and potentially toxic effects.

 

Option C. Emphysema: Morphine has a depressive effect on the respiratory center in the brain, leading to respiratory depression. In patients with emphysema, a condition already characterized by compromised respiratory function, morphine can exacerbate respiratory difficulties and decrease the drive to breathe.

 

Educational Objective :

 

Morphine is beneficial and not contraindicated in the management of acute myocardial infarction (AMI) as it helps to relieve pain, reduce anxiety, and decrease myocardial oxygen demand.

questions.text: If the lung is allowed to undergo elastic recoil without the chest wall, the resultant volume of the lung would be? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Minimum volume

 

If lung is allowed to undergo elastic recoil without the chest wall, the resultant volume of the lung would be minimum volume. This is due to the inherent elastic properties of the lung tissue, which tend to make the lungs contract inward when not counteracted by the outward elastic recoil of the chest wall.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Zero: Incorrect. The lung cannot have zero volume due to the presence of air in the alveoli and residual airways even at its minimal state.

 

Option C. Functional residual capacity: Incorrect. Functional residual capacity (FRC) is the volume of air present in the lungs at the end of passive expiration, which includes the balance between the inward recoil of the lungs and the outward recoil of the chest wall.

 

Option D. Residual volume: Incorrect. Residual volume (RV) is the volume of air remaining in the lungs after a maximal exhalation. The minimum volume after elastic recoil without the chest wall support would be less than the residual volume.

 

Educational Objective:

 

If the lung undergoes elastic recoil without the chest wall, it would collapse to its minimum volume due to the lung's inherent elastic properties.

choices.text: Digit span forward up to 7 digits with 2 skips allowed
Digit span backwards up to 5 digits with 2 skips allowed

questions.text: Which of the following is the test for immediate memory? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Digit span forward up to 7 digits with 2 skips allowed

 

This is the classic test for immediate memory. The patient is asked to repeat a sequence of digits (usually ranging from 5 to 9 numbers), and it tests the capacity of one's immediate memory.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Serial (100-7) subtraction test up to 5 steps: This tests concentration.

 

Option C. Digit span backwards up to 5 digits with 2 skips allowed: This is more challenging than the forward span and is used to assess working memory.

 

Option D. Serial (20-1) subtraction test up to 5 steps: Like the serial (100-7) test, it's more of an assessment for concentration.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The digit span forward test, which involves repeating a sequence of numbers, is a measure of immediate memory and is a fundamental aspect of cognitive assessments.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 13.

questions.text: In conventional oxygen therapy, which device will deliver the highest FiO2? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Non-rebreathing mask

 

  • FiO2 Delivery: A non-rebreathing mask can deliver an FiO2 of up to 80% at flow rates of 10-15 L/min. This mask has a reservoir bag that fills with oxygen and a one-way valve that prevents the exhaled air from entering the reservoir bag, ensuring a higher concentration of oxygen is inhaled.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Venturi mask: The Venturi mask delivers a precise FiO2, which can range from 24% to 66%, depending on the entrainment device used. It is often used in patients who require a specific oxygen concentration.

 

Option B. Hudson mask: This option appears to refer to a simple face mask, which can deliver up to 60% FiO2 at 10 L/min. It is less efficient in delivering high concentrations of oxygen compared to a non-rebreathing mask.

 

Option D. Nasal cannula: A nasal cannula typically delivers up to 44% FiO2 at a flow rate of 6 L/min. It is comfortable and used for patients who need low to moderate oxygen supplementation but cannot deliver the high concentrations achievable with a non-rebreathing mask.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The non-rebreathing mask delivers the highest FiO2 in conventional oxygen therapy, capable of providing up to 80% FiO2 at flow rates of 10-15 L/min, making it suitable for patients requiring high concentrations of oxygen.

questions.text: Which is not an obvious advantage of high-flow nasal cannula? (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Decreases need of intubation

 

Explanation:

 

 

  • Decreases need of intubation: While high-flow nasal cannula (HFNC) can be an intermediate step between standard oxygen therapy and more invasive respiratory support, it doesn't always eliminate the need for intubation. HFNC can improve oxygenation and reduce the work of breathing in many patients, but it may not be sufficient in cases of severe respiratory failure where intubation becomes necessary.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Reduces nasopharyngeal dead space: High-flow nasal cannula allows for the delivery of oxygen at much higher flow rates than standard nasal cannulae. This higher flow rate can flush out the nasopharyngeal dead space, leading to a more consistent fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) and improving alveolar ventilation.

 

Option C. Heating and humidification: One of the distinct features of HFNC systems is that they deliver oxygen that's both heated and humidified. This enhances comfort, reduces the risk of mucosal drying and injury, and can help improve mucociliary clearance.

 

Option D. PEEP (Positive End-Expiratory Pressure): PEEP refers to the maintenance of a positive pressure in the airways at the end of expiration, which can prevent alveolar collapse. The high flow rate from HFNC can generate a degree of PEEP, especially with the mouth closed. This can help recruit alveoli and improve oxygenation in certain patients.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • While high-flow nasal cannula (HFNC) offers several advantages, including reducing nasopharyngeal dead space, providing heated and humidified oxygen, and generating PEEP, it does not always eliminate the need for intubation in patients with severe respiratory failure.

questions.text: A patient was started on Amitryptiline and he was found to be unconscious. Which of the following doesn’t suggest TCA toxicity ?(INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hypothermia

 

TCA toxicity typically presents with hyperthermia due to anticholinergic effects, not hypothermia.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Arrhythmias: Arrhythmias are a hallmark of TCA toxicity, reflecting its impact on cardiac conductivity.

 

Option B. Confusion: Confusion or altered sensorium is common due to the central nervous system effects of TCAs.

 

Option D. Pupillary dilatation: Pupillary dilatation results from the anticholinergic properties of TCAs.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

In cases of TCA toxicity, we see symptoms like arrhythmias, confusion, and pupillary dilatation due to its anticholinergic and cardiotoxic properties. Hypothermia is not typically associated with TCA overdose.

questions.text: A patient is undergoing modified radical neck dissection (MRND) for laryngeal malignancy. While ligating the internal jugular vein, his ETCO2 dropped from 40 mmHg to 14 mmHg, and the patient developed hypotension along with cardiac arrhythmia. Which of the following is the most likely cause? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Venous air embolism

 

Explanation:

 

Venous Air Embolism:

 

  • Definition: It refers to the entry of air into the venous system, which can then travel to the heart and block the pulmonary circulation.
  • Presentation: A sudden drop in ETCO2, hypotension, and potential cardiac arrhythmias. A "mill wheel" murmur might be heard on auscultation.
  • Relevance to the Scenario: The sudden drop in ETCO2, combined with hypotension and cardiac arrhythmia following manipulation of the internal jugular vein during surgery in a head-up position, strongly suggests venous air embolism.

 

There are four important events here:

  1. Bleeding from the internal jugular vein (severed vein which can entrap air)
  2. A drastic fall in ETCO2
  3. Hypotension
  4. Neck surgery – requires head-up position which reduces blood pressure in neck veins

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sympathetic Overactivity:

  • Definition: It refers to excessive stimulation of the sympathetic nervous system.
  • Presentation: It typically manifests as hypertension (raised blood pressure) and tachycardia (increased heart rate).
  • Relevance to the Scenario: The patient developed hypotension, not hypertension, so this option is less likely.

 

Option B. Vagal Stimulation:

  • Definition: Activation of the vagus nerve, one of the cranial nerves, which plays a role in controlling the heart, lungs, and digestive tract.
  • Presentation: Vagal stimulation can cause bradycardia (slowed heart rate) and hypotension.
  • Relevance to the Scenario: While vagal stimulation can explain the hypotension and arrhythmia, it does not account for the drastic drop in ETCO2.

 

Option D. Carotid Body Stimulation:

  • Definition: The carotid body is a small cluster of chemoreceptors located at the bifurcation of the carotid artery. It monitors changes in blood oxygen levels.
  • Presentation: Stimulation can cause changes in heart rate and blood pressure, but it typically results in hypertension.
  • Relevance to the Scenario: Given that the patient is hypotensive, this option is less likely.

 

Educational Objective :

 

  • A sudden drop in ETCO2, hypotension, and cardiac arrhythmias during surgery, especially involving the internal jugular vein and head-up positioning, strongly suggests venous air embolism.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pgs 1878-1880

questions.text: Least frequency of slow waves is seen in? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Stomach

 

Among the given options, the least frequency of slow waves is seen in the stomach (4/min).

 

Most gastrointestinal contractions occur rhythmically, and this rhythm is determined mainly by the frequency of so-called “slow waves” of smooth muscle membrane potential or basal electrical rhythm.

 

Interactions among the smooth muscle cells and specialized cells, called the interstitial cells of Cajal, that are believed to act as electrical pacemakers for smooth muscle cells.

 

They are slow, undulating changes in the resting membrane potential. Their intensity usually varies between 5 and 15 millivolts, and their frequency ranges in different parts of the human gastrointestinal tract from 3 to 12 per minute:

 

  • Body of the stomach – 3/min
  • Duodenum – 12/min
  • Terminal ileum – 8-9/min
  • Distal ileum: 8/min
  • Cecum: 2/min
  • Sigmoid colon: 6/min

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Duodenum: Incorrect. The duodenum has a higher frequency of slow waves, approximately 12 waves per minute.

 

Option B. Ileum: Incorrect. The terminal ileum has a frequency of about 8-9 waves per minute.

 

Option C. Jejunum: Incorrect. The jejunum has a frequency of approximately 10-12 waves per minute.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The stomach has the least frequency of slow waves among the given options, with approximately 3 waves per minute. Slow waves determine the rhythmic contractions of the gastrointestinal tract and vary in frequency throughout different regions.

choices.text: Is commonly associated with concomitant hypothyroidism
Characterised by at least four distinct episodes per year

questions.text: Rapid cycling in bipolar disorder is characterised by all of the following features except: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Occurs more commonly in men

 

  • Rapid cycling in bipolar disorder is defined by having four or more distinct mood episodes (mania, hypomania, or depression) within a single year.
  • This condition is more commonly observed in females.
  • Several factors, including hypothyroidism and substance abuse, can contribute to the likelihood of rapid cycling.
  • Additionally, the use of antidepressants has been found to increase the risk of triggering rapid cycling episodes.
  • Mood stabilizer of choice - Valproate

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Is commonly associated with concomitant hypothyroidism: This statement is correct. Hypothyroidism is known to be associated with an increased risk of rapid cycling in bipolar disorder.

 

Option C. Characterised by at least four distinct episodes per year: This statement is correct. The definition of rapid cycling specifically includes the occurrence of four or more mood episodes in one calendar year.

 

Option D. Antidepressants increase the likelihood: This statement is correct. The use of antidepressants can indeed increase the likelihood of rapid cycling in individuals with bipolar disorder.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rapid cycling in bipolar disorder is more commonly seen in females and is characterized by at least four distinct episodes per year.

choices.text: Strength of muscle contraction
Intensity of stimulus
Amplitude of action potential
Duration of stimulus

questions.text: Weber-Fechner law relates magnitude of sensation to? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Intensity of stimulus

 

The Weber-Fechner law is a psychophysical law that describes the relationship between the magnitude of a physical stimulus and the perceived intensity of the resulting sensation.

 

According to this law, the perceived magnitude of a sensory stimulus is proportional to the logarithm of the stimulus intensity. In other words, as the intensity of the stimulus increases, the change needed to produce a noticeable difference in sensation also increases, and this relationship is logarithmic rather than linear.

 

The law was first formulated by the German scientists Ernst Heinrich Weber and Gustav Theodor Fechner in the mid-19th century and has since been applied to a wide range of sensory modalities, including vision, hearing, and touch.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Strength of muscle contraction: This is unrelated to the Weber-Fechner law, which does not concern muscle contraction.

 

Option C. Amplitude of action potential: While action potentials are critical for neural transmission, the Weber-Fechner law specifically relates to the perception of stimulus intensity, not the electrical properties of neurons.

 

Option D. Duration of stimulus: The duration of a stimulus affects perception in different ways but is not the focus of the Weber-Fechner law.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Weber-Fechner law illustrates the logarithmic relationship between the actual intensity of a stimulus and the perceived intensity, emphasizing that the human sensory system scales the perception of stimulus magnitude logarithmically rather than linearly.

 

Additional information Other Laws in Physiology:

 

  • Doctrine of specific nerve energies states that the nature of perception is defined by the pathway over which the sensory information is carried. Hence, the origin of the sensation is not important.
  • Law of projection - Regardless of stimulation point for a particular sensory pathway (along its course to cortex), conscious sensation produced is referred to the location of receptor.

questions.text: A patient says that he feels that there is something wrong with him mentally and it is because of the summer season. How much would he score on the insight scale? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 3

 

The insight scale is graded from 1 to 5. In this scenario, the patient recognizes that there's something wrong with him mentally, which signifies some level of insight. However, he attributes it to the summer season, an external factor. This corresponds to a score of 3, which is recognition of a mental illness but blaming it on external causes.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Insight is graded from 1 to 5.

 

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Comprehensive Textbook of Psychiatry, 10th edition, Page No 967.

questions.text: You are attending physiology viva. The examiner asks you who recorded the first EEG. You say "I don't know "The examiner feels bad for you and gives you a clue that "the name sounds like something you get commonly in McDonalds". You remember the name and answer correctly. What type of memory has been implicated here?" (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Priming

 

Priming is when exposure to a stimulus influences the response to a subsequent stimulus. In this scenario, the examiner's hint about McDonald's (suggesting "burger") facilitated the student's recall of "Berger," who recorded the first EEG.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Semantic memory: Semantic memory involves facts and general knowledge, like knowing the capital of a country.

 

Option B. Implicit memory: Implicit memory is unconscious, but involves skills or tasks, like riding a bike.

 

Option C. Associative learning: Associative learning involves pairing two stimuli, like Pavlov's dog experiment.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Priming means that a recent experience makes it easier for you to notice or identify something related.

 

Perceptual Priming: Recognizing something becomes easier because you've recently seen something that looks similar. For example, if you've just seen a picture of a lion, you'll be faster at spotting the word "lion" even if it's a bit unclear.

 

Conceptual Priming: Understanding or noticing something becomes easier because you've recently thought about a related idea. For example, if you've just read about rivers and banks, you'll probably guess the word "bank" when given "ban_" instead of thinking of "band."

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 116.

choices.text: Closure of active gates of sodium channel
Closure of inactive gates of sodium channel

questions.text: Absolute refractory period is due to? (AIIMS NOVEMBER 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Closure of inactive gates of sodium channel

 

The absolute refractory period is due to the closure of the inactive gates of sodium channels. During this period, a second action potential cannot be elicited, even with a strong stimulus. A new action potential cannot occur in an excitable fiber as long as the membrane is still depolarized from the preceding action potential. This is because shortly after the action potential is initiated, the sodium channels become inactivated, and no amount of excitatory signal applied to these channels at this point will open the inactivation gates.

 

Other Options:

 

Option  A. Opening of calcium channels: Incorrect. The opening of calcium channels is not related to the absolute refractory period.

 

Option B. Closure of potassium channels: Incorrect. The closure of potassium channels does not define the absolute refractory period.

 

Option C. Closure of active gates of sodium channel: Incorrect. The closure of active gates does not account for the absolute refractory period.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The absolute refractory period is due to the closure of the inactive gates of sodium channels, preventing the initiation of a new action potential during this period.

questions.text: Abrupt stoppage of which of the following drugs causes agitation, anxiety and insomnia? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Venlafaxine

 

Abrupt discontinuation or dose reduction of venlafaxine has been known to result in a discontinuation syndrome characterized by agitation, anxiety, and insomnia. This is particularly noted with venlafaxine because of its short half-life. While all the drugs listed can have withdrawal symptoms if stopped suddenly, venlafaxine is particularly associated with these symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Valproate: Abrupt discontinuation can lead to seizure recurrence in those using it as an antiepileptic and can cause relapse of mood symptoms in those using it as mood stabilizer.

 

Option B. Olanzapine: Stopping it can result in a return of psychotic symptoms.

 

Option C. Imipramine: It can cause withdrawal symptoms, but they are typically more varied and might include headache, nausea, and malaise.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The key features of antidepressant discontinuation syndrome, often abbreviated as FINISH:

 

  • Flu-like symptoms
  • Insomnia
  • Nausea
  • Imbalance
  • Sensory disturbances (e.g., electric shock sensations)
  • Hyperarousal (e.g., anxiety, agitation).

 

It is particularly common with SSRIs and SNRIs with shorter half-lives, such as venlafaxine (most common). Short acting SSRIs such as paroxetine and fluvoxamine are also commonly associated with discontinuation syndrome. Gradual tapering and patient education are essential to prevent and manage this syndrome.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Comprehensive Textbook of Psychiatry, 10th edition, Page No 3150.

questions.text: Which of the following hormones play a permissive role in the attainment of puberty? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Leptin

 

The hormone that plays a permissive role in the attainment of puberty is leptin.

 

Leptin is a peptide hormone released from adipocytes

 

Leptin plays an important role in controlling the adipose tissue and food intake.

 

Actions of leptin:

 

  • Acts on hypothalamus and inhibits the feeding center, resulting in stoppage of food intake
